Ruthenium catalyst supported on high-surface-area basic ZrO2 for ammonia synthesis Wang Zi-qing Ma Yun-cui Lin Jian-xin ⁎ National Engineering Research Center of Chemical Fertilizer Catalyst, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou 350002, Fujian, China National Engineering Research Center of Chemical Fertilizer Catalyst, Fuzhou University Fuzhou Fujian 350002 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 591 83731234x8102. Graphical abstract The superbasic ZrO2 (ZrO2-KOH) with high surface area was prepared by reflux-digestion of ZrO(OH)2 gel in mother liquor and examined as a support promoting ammonia synthesis by particulate Ru. The TEM image of Ru/ZrO2-KOH catalyst indicates that the size of Ru particles is in the range of 1.5–3.2nm, which is the optimum size of Ru particles for the maximum number of B5-type sites. Additionally, the characterizations including CO2-TPD, XPS and N2-TPD demonstrate that the Ru particles supported on ZrO2-KOH exhibit higher electron density compared to that of Ru/ZrO2 catalyst. As a result, the dissociative adsorption of N2 over Ru/ZrO2-KOH is more facile than that over Ru/ZrO2 catalyst. Thus, the Ru/ZrO2-KOH catalyst shows an excellent activity for ammonia synthesis especially under the conditions of low temperature and pressure. The highest reaction rate of Ru/ZrO2-KOH is 16.91mmol/(gh) at 698K and 3.0MPa, which is much higher than that of various Ru catalysts supported on other supports. Keywords Ruthenium catalyst Ammonia synthesis Zirconia Basicity Dispersion 1 Introduction Ammonia is an important feedstock for the chemical industry, which has been produced by reacting H2 and N2 in the presence of iron catalysts since 1913 [1,2]. However, this process is a very energy- and capital-intensive industry, as it requires high temperature and pressure for its daily operations. Hence, searching for a new catalyst operating under milder conditions has been a research focus in catalysis area for several years [3–8]. Of all these catalysts, only carbon-supported Ru catalysts have been used for industrial ammonia synthesis since the 1990s [9]. To overcome the significant drawback of using activated carbon supports that are prone to methanation under the temperature and pressure of ammonia synthesis, many stable supports, such as MgO, Al2O3, CeO2, zeolite and other porous nano-materials, were studied with the aim of preparing Ru-based catalysts with high activity [10–16]. Among the desired properties of a support, high-surface area and basicity rank very high, and thus ZrO2 was not considered to be an ideal support for Ru catalyst because of the acidic nature and low surface area of that [17]. Therefore, there are few reports involving the application of ZrO2 as a support for Ru-based catalyst in ammonia synthesis reaction. However, we should come to realize that the properties of ZrO2 are easily adjustable by simple chemical methods. For example, treatment with H2SO4, KF or KNO3 can generate superacidic and superbasic ZrO2, respectively [18]. It has been shown that digestion of ZrO(OH)2, which is the initial product from precipitation of zirconium salts, improved several properties of the calcined product ZrO2, such as increase surface area, change the structure and improve thermal stability, etc. [19,20]. The idea has long since been proved that the rate of ammonia synthesis was relative with the basicity of support because basic support can donate electrons to Ru atoms [21,22]. In addition, large surface area is generally regarded as a favorable factor for Ru dispersion. Evidently, the ideal Ru/ZrO2 catalysts with high activity for ammonia synthesis could be obtained by some appropriate methods. Sun et al. [23] have successfully prepared Ru/ZrO2 catalysts by supporting Ru on the high-surface-area zirconia and used to catalytic wet oxidation of N,N-dimethyl formamide. They found that the activity was much higher than those catalysts prepared by conventional methods. Yin et al. [20] also reported that the KOH modified ZrO2 was an excellent support for Ru-based catalyst in the reaction of hydrogen production from the ammonia decomposition. However, up to now there has been no previous report on use of ZrO2 as the support for a Ru-based ammonia synthesis catalyst. The present work is related to catalytic ammonia synthesis over Ru catalyst supported on the high-surface-area zirconia prepared by digestion of ZrO(OH)2 in the mother liquor. For better understanding the relationships between structure and catalytic performance for Ru/ZrO2-KOH, other Ru catalysts supported on Al2O3, MgO and conventional ZrO2 were also prepared by the same way. The characterization such as X-ray diffraction (XRD), BET surface area, temperature-programmed desorptions of NH3, CO2 and N2 (NH3-TPD, CO2-TPD and N2-TPD), TEM and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were carried out to get a closer insight into these catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts The superbasic ZrO2 (ZrO2-KOH) with high surface area was prepared following a similar procedure described in reference [19]. 1.0mol/L KOH solution was added dropwise to ZrO(NO3)2 solutions under stirring at room temperature until the resulting solution pH leveled at 10.50. The formed ZrO(OH)2 hydrogel was divided into two portions: one was digested in its mother solution at 369K for 24h while the other was left in mother solution to age at room temperature for 24h. Then, the mixture solution were filtered and simultaneously washed with deionized water for three times. Finally, both the obtained resultants were dried at 373K overnight, and followed calcinations at 823K for 3h. The zirconium oxides from digestion and aging were referred to as ZrO2-KOH and ZrO2, respectively. The Ru catalysts promoted with K were prepared by incipient-wet impregnation process using aqueous solution of K2RuO4 followed by drying in air at 383K for 12h and reduced with absolute ethyl alcohol, then treated with H2 at 723K for 4h. As measured by X-ray fluorescence, the K content in Ru/ZrO2-KOH was 4.12%. For comparison with other oxides supports, the Al2O3, ZrO2 and MgO were also impregnated with a water solution of K2RuO4 by the same way. In order to eliminate the effect of K, a certain amount of KOH was added to these samples via impregnation method to reach the equal K content with Ru/ZrO2-KOH. The obtained samples were also dried and treated under the same conditions, which were denoted as K-Ru/Al2O3, K-Ru/ZrO2 and K-Ru/MgO, respectively. Additionally, the Ru/ZrO2 without K promoted was obtained by hydrogen reduction of ZrO2 supported Ru (NO)(NO3)3 at 723K for 4h. All the samples were designed to load 4wt% Ru. 2.2 Measurements of catalytic activities for ammonia synthesis The catalyst activity for ammonia synthesis was measured in a stainless steel reactor. Before testing, the catalysts were activated in a flowing gas mixture of 75% H2 and 25% N2 from ambient temperature to 723K at 1K/min (kept at 473, 573 and 723K for 2h, respectively) and then stabilized under the reaction conditions (i.e. 3MPa, 673K, 10,000h−1, and H2/N2 volume ratio of 3) for more than 2h. The ammonia concentration in the effluent was determined by a chemical titration method. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts N2 physisorption was measured on the gas adsorption instrument Nova Win2, then the surface area was obtained by BET equation and pore volume take P/P 0 =0.99 when the corresponding adsorption volume. XRD analysis was carried out on a PANalytical X’pert Pro diffractometer system, using CoKa radiation (0.1789nm). The basicity of the supports was evaluated by temperature-programmed desorption of carbon dioxide (CO2-TPD) using an AutoChem 2910 instrument (Mciromeritics) and the detector was mass analyzer from Hakuto Enterprise (Shang Hai) Ltd. The sample was treated at 773K for 2h under a flow of He atmosphere (flow rate of 30mlmin−1). After being cooled down to room temperature, pure CO2 was adsorbed at room temperature for 1.5h. Then the physisorbed CO2 was removed by a flushing with He at room temperature for 1.5h. TPD was carried out in the stream of He (20mlmin−1) at a heating rate of 10K up to 1073K (all the samples were 100mg) [22]. The procedure for the NH3-TPD experiments was similar to that of CO2-TPD. The carrier gas was pure He and the adsorption temperature is 373K, and the gases for adsorption were 5% NH3/He. The N2-TPD experiment was carried out by the same instrument as CO2-TPD and the procedure is similar to that described previously [36]. The catalyst (100mg) was treated at 773K for 2h under a flow of hydrogen. Then the gas flow was switched to pure He for purging at 773K for 1h, and the gas flow was switched to N2 and the sample was cooled slowly to 423K and kept for 1h. Subsequently, the sample was cooled to room temperature and gas flow was switched to pure He (40mlmin−1) before the temperature ramp was started. The N2-TPD experiment was performed by sample heating at a rate of 15K/min from 323K to 773K. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy with monochromatized Al Kα X-rays (hν =1486.6eV) radiation (XPS, ThermoFisher Scientific Co. ESCALAB 250, USA) was used to investigate the surface properties [24]. TEM was performed on a FEITecnai G2 F20 field emission transmission electron microscope operated at 200kV. The Ru dispersion was calculated by the methods proposed by Borodziński [25]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD and BET The XRD patterns of supports and catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . According to the result, the ZrO2 is the mixture of the two phases: monoclinic (2θ =32.8 and 36.6) and cubic (2θ =35.1 and 59.2), while ZrO2-KOH sample is predominantly cubic. The result demonstrates that the crystal structure formed after precipitation can be altered by digestion, which is well in agreement with the previous results [19,20]. After supported Ru, the diffraction of K-Ru/ZrO2 and Ru/ZrO2-KOH remained unchanged with their supports, no peak of the ruthenium phase could be observed, indicating that Ru particles are probably well dispersed on the supports. The texture properties of supports are listed in Table 1 . The specific surface area of ZrO2-KOH is 198m2/g, which is almost 4.5 times of that for ZrO2. It indicates that the reflux-digestion process would lead to the increase in BET surface area and total pore volume, which is in good accord with the results reported by literature [20,26]. 3.2 The acidity and basicity of catalysts It is well known that the catalytic performance of Ru-based catalyst for ammonia synthesis is closely related to the surface acidity and basicity of catalyst, the presence of some acid sites would lead to withdraw electron and decrease the activity. The surface acidity of the present catalysts determined by NH3-TPD is shown in Fig. 2 , and the amount of chemisorbed NH3 on these catalysts is given in Table 3 . Compared with the result of Ru/Al2O3 and Ru/MgO catalyst in literature [21], the desorption peak of NH3 over K-Ru/Al2O3 and K-Ru/MgO is only slightly weakened, indicating that the addition of KOH has little influence on the decrease in the amount and strength of acidic sites. However, one can see that the amount of NH3 desorbed on Ru/ZrO2-KOH was approximately 0.32μmol/m2, only 1/5 of that adsorbed on K-Ru/ZrO2 (1.55μmol/m2), demonstrating that the reflux-digestion in mother solution can make the K contact with the strong acid sites sufficiently that lead to much more strong acid sites that were neutralized and decrease the amount of acidic sites. The basicity of the catalysts determined by CO2-TPD is shown in Fig. 3 . It can be seen that CO2-TPD spectra of Ru/ZrO2-KOH and Ru/K-ZrO2 have a broad adsorption curve for CO2 at high-temperature from 723K to 1073K and with two low-temperature peaks around 373K and 395K. These peaks correspond to the desorptions of CO2 for strong basic and weak basic sites, respectively. The unusually strong basicity appeared on Ru/ZrO2-KOH are main resulted from the decomposition and dispersion of the loaded KOH, which is consistent with the studied a series of K/ZrO2 solid superbase with different KNO3 [18,27,28]. One also can see from Fig. 3 and Table 3 that the number of basic sites of Ru/ZrO2-KOH are much higher than that of KOH loading on ZrO2, indicating that the number of basic site is not only concerned with the content of potassium but also with the surface area of support. In addition, it is evident that the high temperature of CO2 desorption over Ru/ZrO2-KOH and K-Ru/ZrO2 is much higher than those for K-Ru/MgO and K-Ru/Al2O3, signifying that the basicity strength formation of KOH loading on ZrO2 is stronger than that of KOH loading on other supports. Thus, it was logical to conclude that the interface or interaction of K species and ZrO2 is very different from that of K and MgO or Al2O3. Indeed, some literatures reported that the presence of rich vacant sites on the surface of ZrO2 was crucial for dissociated dispersion and decomposition of K salt [18]. Then the highly dispersed K+ would insert into the vacant site and occupy the position of octa-coordinated Zr4+ to form a strong basic site [27,28]. Simultaneously, they also found that no basicity was formed on other oxides supported K salt systems in ambient conditions because of lack of an octahedral vacant for K+ ion insertion. Therefore, the intensity of basic sites of Ru/ZrO2-KOH and K-Ru/ZrO2 is much stronger than that of K-Ru/Al2O3 and K-Ru/MgO. Additionally, the high surface area and the reflux-digestion process could lead to an increase in the amount of surface vacant sites for K modification, which could explain why Ru/ZrO2-KOH possesses so many basic sites. Contrasting Ru/ZrO2-KOH and K-Ru/ZrO2 with Ru/ZrO2 in CO2-TPD date, it is evident that the addition of KOH would have two functions on supported catalysts: one is the direct electronic interaction with the Ru mental as promoter and the other is an indirect interaction with the support to induce stronger basicity. This is also in good accord with the effect of KOH loading on activated carbon support reported by Liang and co-workers [29]. 3.3 TEM Fig. 4 shows the TEM micrographs of K-promoted Ru catalyst supported on various supports, and the average size and dispersion of Ru particles based on TEM are listed in Table 2. As we can see from Fig. 4(a), the micrograph displays rather uniform particles size dispersion with size ranging from 1.5nm to 3.2nm. According to the d n =∑n i d i /∑n i equation in Ref. [30], the average size of Ru particles was about 2.2nm that is close to optimum particle size of 2nm [12,31,32]. However, TEM image of the K-Ru/ZrO2 reveals that Ru particle sizes are approximately 3.2–8.5nm that is much larger than that of Ru/ZrO2-KOH. We also found that the average size of Ru particles of K-Ru/ZrO2 is around 6.4nm. It also can be observed from Table 2 that the Ru dispersion for Ru/ZrO2-KOH based on the average Ru particle size in TEM is 48.2%, which is about more than 2.3, 2.8, and 1.5 times of that for K-Ru/ZrO2, K-Ru/MgO and K-Ru/Al2O3, respectively. It should be noted that there is clear difference in mental Ru particle size and dispersion on the four catalysts, which may be explained by two reasons. One reason is the larger surface area and mesoporous structure of ZrO2-KOH is generally regarded as a favorable factor for good Ru dispersions. And the other may be attributed to the reaction of basic K2RuO4 precursor and the acid centers on the surface of ZrO2 and Al2O3, which results in the anchoring of Ru species and the decrease in Ru dispersion. That is to say, the basicity is also advantageous to the improvement of Ru dispersion. This conclusion is also supported by literature [26,30]. As for K-Ru/MgO catalyst, it is well known that the nano-size Ru metal could not be well dispersed on the MgO support by means of the simple water impregnation due to the formation of Mg(OH)2 [12]. 3.4 XPS Fig. 5 shows the Ru3d core level spectra measured from the Ru/ZrO2 and Ru/ZrO2-KOH samples. The spectra consist of the Ru 3d5/2 and Ru 3d5/2 peaks appearing as a result of a spin-orbital splitting. The Ru 3d5/2 peak is overlapped with the C 1s peak at ∼285eV derived from carbonaceous impurities (CH x ) originally present on the catalyst surface or slowly accumulated in the spectrometer [7,33]. As shown in Fig. 5, the E b (Ru 3d5/2) value of Ru/ZrO2-KOH is 279.6eV, which is 0.6eV lower than the value of E b (Ru 3d5/2) for the bulk Ru mental (280.2eV). The negative shift of the Ru3d core level spectrum with respect to that of Ru mental has been found for Cs-Ru/MgO and Sm-Ru/Al2O3 catalysts [24,33], and this result can be accepted by considering the transfer of electron density from the basic support or promoter to supported Ru particles. On the other hand, Ru 3d5/2 binding energy for Ru/ZrO2 is ca. 280.5eV, which has also been observed in Ru mental for Ru/AC and Ru/Al2O3 catalysts [7,34,35]. This phenomenon can be ascribed to the acidic sites on the surface of ZrO2, which withdraw electron density from Ru atoms and increase the Ru 3d5/2 binding energy. 3.5 N2-TPD Shown in Fig. 6 are the N2-TPD patterns of Ru/ZrO2, Ru/K-ZrO2 and Ru/ZrO2-KOH. The amount and peak temperature of N2 desorption over the three catalysts are also collected in Table 3. For the Ru/ZrO2 catalyst, N2 desorption begins at 500K and shows a maximum at 594K, with the reflux-digestion in mother solution, the values are 502K and 563K. Over K-Ru/ZrO2 catalyst, the values are 450K and 556K. Obviously, the temperature of maximum desorption of Ru/ZrO2-KOH and K-Ru/ZrO2 shift of 31K and 38K to lower temperature in comparison of that over Ru/ZrO2 catalyst, suggesting that modification of ZrO2 with potassium could promote N2 desorption, the similar results were also found in literatures [36,37]. One also can see in Table 3 that there are no remarkable differences in the amount of N2 desorption over Ru/ZrO2 (17.4μmol/g) and K-Ru/ZrO2 (20.3μmol/g). However, the amount of N2 desorbed over Ru/ZrO2-KOH was 26.5μmol/g, which was much more than that of Ru/ZrO2 and K-Ru/ZrO2. This may have resulted from the high surface area of ZrO2-KOH caused by an increase in the amount of Ru particles exposed on the surface of support. Interestingly, a low-temperature peak concentrated at about 400K also can be found in the N2-TPD profile for K-Ru/MgO, which is different from that of the similar system (Ru/MgO) in Ref. [38]. Most recently, Lin et al. [39] also observed a new peak at the same position appearing in the Ru/AC system due to the addition of K promoter and the K loading had a significant effect on the position and amount of N2 desorption peak at low temperature. Thus, we propose that the low temperature peak for K-Ru/MgO also should be ascribed to the presence of K promoter. Additionally, there is no peak detected in other catalysts, which may have resulted from the different nature of support or K state. The N2-TPD disclose the lower temperature of N2 desorption means lower apparent activation energy over the Ru catalysts, which is advantageous to the ammonia synthesis [30,36]. We also observed the similar results in the most recent publication [40]. 3.6 Catalytic activity for ammonia synthesis Table 4 compares the rates of ammonia synthesis over Ru catalysts supported on various supports. It is obvious that within the temperature range of 673–698K, the order of activities can be ranked as Ru/ZrO2-KOH>K-Ru/MgO>K-Ru/ZrO2 >K-Ru/Al2O3 >Ru/ZrO2, signifying that Ru/ZrO2-KOH is the most active. The ammonia concentration and rate activity over Ru/ZrO2-KOH is up to 6.05% and 16.91mmol/(gcat h) at 698K, 3MPa and 10,000h−1, respectively. This activity is also even superior to that reported for 4wt% K-Ru/AC and K-Ru/GNFs under the similar conditions [2,29]. Moreover, the present activity is also much higher than that of Ru/Sm2O3, Ru/MgO, Ru/La2O3, Sm-Ru/Al2O3 and Sm-Ru/CCA, although the latter catalysts’ activity was measured under the much harsher conditions (10MPa)[9,10,24,40]. In order to further understand the catalytic performance of Ru/ZrO2-KOH catalyst for ammonia synthesis, the effect of reaction temperature and pressure on the activity is investigated and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . For the Ru/ZrO2-KOH catalyst with 4.0wt% Ru loading, ammonia synthesis increases as reaction temperature increased. Obviously, the ammonia concentration in the effluent no longer increases and begin to decreases when the temperature above 698K, due to a thermodynamic equilibrium limitation. In addition, it is clearly observed that ammonia concentration in the effluent is significantly increased when the reaction pressure is increased from 1MPa to 3MPa. Then the ammonia synthesis activity is only slightly decreased when the reaction pressure is beyond 3MPa. The low activity at 1.0–3.0MPa should be resulting from the limitation of thermodynamic equilibrium while H2 poisoning will appear in the condition of higher pressure on the surface of Ru/ZrO2 catalyst; the hydrogen poisoning would become much more serious with the reaction pressure increase [41,42]. From the result of Fig. 7(b), it obviously can be concluded that the catalytic activity of Ru/ZrO2-KOH is inhibited by chemisorbed hydrogen at high pressure (>3.0MPa). Moreover, the most recent literature found that the addition of potassium promoter can further improve hydrogen absorption [39]. From the activity date, it is evident that high surface area basic ZrO2 is an outstanding support of Ru catalyst for ammonia synthesis, especially under the low pressure condition. The reason why this catalyst exhibits superior activity for ammonia synthesis to the Ru catalysts supported on other oxides at least lies in the following two factors. One reason is the high dispersion and the appropriate Ru particles size on this support. It was well acceptable that the ammonia synthesis over Ru catalyst is a structure sensitive reaction and the B5-type site is responsible for the activity for ammonia synthesis, and the maximum number of B5-tye site is obtained when the Ru particles size is about 2nm [31,32,43]. In our study, Fig. 4(a) shows the TEM image of Ru/ZrO2-KOH after reaction revealing the presence of uniform Ru particles ranging from 1.5 to 3.2nm on the support, exhibiting a high utilization ratio of Ru and the optimum particles sizes possessing more B5-type sites. The other reason is the strong and rich basic sites on the surface of the support. The formation of basic sites on ZrO2 is much easier than that on Al2O3 because of the rich vacant sites only existing in the structure of ZrO2, when some contents of K were loaded on them. It is also indicate the reason why K is not considered to be a promising promoter for Al2O3 supported Ru catalysts for ammonia synthesis. The effect of basic support on the activity of Ru catalysts for ammonia synthesis usually was explained by their ability to donate electrons to the Ru atoms; the excess electrons transferred from the d-orbital of Ru atoms to anti-bonding orbital of N2 and facilitated the dissociation of N [21,22,44]. This process also can be observed in present work from the results of CO2-TPD, XPS and N2-TPD in Ru/ZrO2-KOH system. 4 Conclusions The superbasic ZrO2 with high surface area of 198m2/g was prepared by digestion of hydrous zirconia in the mother liquor and examined as the support of Ru-based catalyst for ammonia synthesis. Compared with the reaction temperature over K-Ru/ZrO2, K-Ru/MgO, K-Ru/Al2O3 and other Ru catalysts reported in previous literature, the catalytic activity of Ru/ZrO2-KOH catalyst shows the highest activity for ammonia synthesis. Such high activity could be the result of highly dispersed particle of Ru together with the appropriate Ru particles size on the support and the strong basicity after KOH loading. coredata.dc:description: The superbasic ZrO2 (ZrO2-KOH) with high surface area was prepared by reflux-digestion of ZrO(OH)2 gel in mother liquor and examined as a support promoting ammonia synthesis by particulate Ru. The TEM image of Ru/ZrO2-KOH catalyst indicates that the size of Ru particles is in the range of 1.5–3.2nm, which is the optimum size of Ru particles for the maximum number of B5-type sites. Additionally, the characterizations including CO2-TPD, XPS and N2-TPD demonstrate that the Ru particles supported on ZrO2-KOH exhibit higher electron density compared to that of Ru/ZrO2 catalyst. As a result, the dissociative adsorption of N2 over Ru/ZrO2-KOH is more facile than that over Ru/ZrO2 catalyst. Thus, the Ru/ZrO2-KOH catalyst shows an excellent activity for ammonia synthesis especially under the conditions of low temperature and pressure. The highest reaction rate of Ru/ZrO2-KOH is 16.91mmol/(gh) at 698K and 3.0MPa, which is much higher than that of various Ru catalysts supported on other supports.
coredata.dc:title: Ruthenium catalyst supported on high-surface-area basic ZrO2 for ammonia synthesis

coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
